name: Taking it slow
description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

key_work.title: Phantom Ride
key_work.credit_line:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Daniel Crooks is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery, Australia and Future Perfect, Singapore
key_work.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, colour and audio
key_work.brief_description: Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

constellations_primary.name: Taking it slow
constellations_primary.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

constellations_other.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_other.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

start.title: A Slow Year

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

end.title: The Clock
end.brief_description: The Clock is a 24-hour video installation created from thousands of clips of clocks, watches and other references to time from film and television.

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

links.description: A Slow Year explores ideas of time – primarily through watching the seasons go by – Christian Marclay’s The Clock connects with time from a granular rather than seasonal perspective, engaging audiences minute by minute through a hundred years of screen history.

start.title: Phantom Ride
start.credit_line:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Daniel Crooks is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery, Australia and Future Perfect, Singapore

start.brief_description: Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

end.title: Bergensbanen Minute By Minute
end.brief_description: Bergensbanen is a real-time documentary film of the entire journey by rail from Bergen to Oslo in Norway.

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

links.description: Harking back to early cinema, when filmmakers hitched cameras to trains so audiences could experience exotic travel, Daniel Crooks’ artwork stitches together slow-moving landscapes and was filmed on disused railway tracks. It’s similar to the slow TV phenomenon exemplified by Bergensbanen.

start.title: Bergensbanen Minute By Minute
start.brief_description: Bergensbanen is a real-time documentary film of the entire journey by rail from Bergen to Oslo in Norway.

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

end.title: A Slow Year
end.brief_description: An Ian Bogost created list of short games.

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

links.description: While Bergensbanen is an antidote to fast-paced TV, A Slow Year is a reaction to the fast pace of contemporary videogames. Deliberately meditative, the game slows itself to a kind of digital poem.

start.title: The Clock
start.brief_description: The Clock is a 24-hour video installation created from thousands of clips of clocks, watches and other references to time from film and television.

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

end.title: Play School
end.brief_description: Play School is an Australian Gold Logie award-winning educational television show for children. It is the longest-running children’s show in Australia, and the second longest-running children’s show in the world.

constellations_other.name: Learning through play
constellations_other.description: Alexander Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead’s Zoetrope to Cinemascope educated children about the moving image through posters, cut-outs, puzzles and games, but moving image works have also been used to educate and entertain kids about all aspects of life.

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

links.description: ABC’s Play School has always featured a clock, with the original rocket and flower clocks assuming iconic status and their removal represented the end of an era. Subsequent clocks have now become symbolic of transience.
